rules: Rule1: Either the studio has a sufficient budget, or the game is successful.
Rule2: If the game receives an industry award, then, provided that it passes quality testing, the game is successful.
Rule3: Whenever the game receives extensive marketing, it also receives funding from a publisher.
Rule4: Under the condition that the studio releases the game product, the project completes development successfully.
Rule5: Provided that the game encounters a minor bug, it is not the case that the game encounters a critical bug.
Rule6: Either the game implements a multiplayer feature, or, if it is not the case that a skilled team at the studio implies a functional game prototype, then the game encounters a minor bug.
Rule7: If the project uses a proprietary engine, then the studio does not have a sufficient budget.
Rule8: Under the condition that the game uses advanced technology, if it implements a multiplayer feature, then it also implements a cross-platform feature.
Rule9: If the game uses a custom engine, then it uses advanced technology.
Rule10: If the game achieves high sales, then it achieves record sales.
Rule11: Either the game achieves high sales, or it receives an industry award.
Rule12: If the game achieves moderate sales, then it does not achieve record sales.
Rule13: Under the condition that the game receives a positive review, it achieves low sales or moderate sales.
Rule14: If the game receives a mixed review, then it achieves low sales or moderate sales.
Rule15: Provided that the game gains viral traction, it receives a positive review or a mixed review.
Rule16: Either the game gains viral traction, or it gains steady traction.
Rule17: If the game gains steady traction, then it receives a positive review or a mixed review.
Rule18: Either the game wins an indie competition, or it wins a mainstream competition.
Rule19: If the game wins a mainstream competition, then, provided that it passes quality testing, the game is successful.
Rule20: Either the development faces a significant delay, or, if the project completes development successfully, then the game is successful.
Rule21: Under the condition that the development faces a minor delay, it does not face a significant delay.
Rule22: If the development faces a negligible delay, then it does not face a significant delay.
Rule23: Provided that the development maintains a tight schedule, it faces a minor delay or a negligible delay.
Rule24: Under the condition that the development maintains a flexible schedule, it faces a minor delay or a negligible delay.
Rule25: If the development meets the alpha milestone, then it maintains a tight schedule.
Rule26: Either the development meets the alpha milestone, or it meets the beta milestone.
Rule27: Provided that the development meets the beta milestone, it maintains a flexible schedule.
Rule28: Under the condition that the development meets the alpha deadline, if the studio has a skilled team, then the game has a functional prototype.
Rule29: Either the development meets the alpha deadline, or it meets the beta deadline.
Rule30: If the development meets the beta deadline, then, provided that the studio has a skilled team, the game has a functional prototype.
Rule31: If it is not the case that releasing the game product implies the game is successful, then the game receives negative criticism.
Rule32: If it is not the case that having partial funding implies adequate funding, then the project has insufficient funding.
Rule33: If it is not the case that having partial funding implies adequate funding, then it is not the case that the project has insufficient funding.
Rule34: If it is not the case that winning an indie competition implies that passing quality testing leads to a successful game, then the game loses the indie competition.
Rule35: If it is not the case that winning an indie competition implies that passing quality testing leads to a successful game, then it is not the case that the game loses the indie competition.
Rule36: If it is not the case that having a committed investor implies adequate funding, then the studio has a skilled team.
Rule37: If it is not the case that having a committed investor implies adequate funding, then it is not the case that the game has a functional prototype.
Rule38: If it is not the case that having a skilled team implies a functional game prototype, then the game encounters a critical bug.
Rule39: If it is not the case that the failure of "releasing the game product implies success" implies no negative criticism, then the studio receives community support.

Rule40: If it is not the case that the failure of "the failure of 'releasing the game product implies success' implies no negative criticism" implies no community support, then the studio receives financial backing.

Rule41: If it is not the case that the failure of "the failure of 'releasing the game product implies success' implies no negative criticism" implies no community support, then it is not the case that the studio receives financial backing.
Rule42: If it is not the case that the failure of "not receiving an industry award implies publisher funding" implies securing a major partnership, then the studio secures a minor partnership.

Rule43: If it is not the case that the failure of "not receiving an industry award implies publisher funding" implies securing a major partnership, then it is not the case that the studio secures a minor partnership.
Rule44: If it is not the case that the game receives an industry award, then it receives extensive marketing.
Rule45: If it is not the case that the game receives an industry award, then it does not receive funding from a publisher.
Rule46: If it is not the case that the project uses a proprietary engine, then it has partial funding.
Rule47: If it is not the case that the project uses a proprietary engine, then it has a committed investor.
Rule48: If it is not the case that the game uses a custom engine, then it uses a licensed engine.
Rule49: If it is not the case that the game uses a custom engine, then it is not the case that it uses a licensed engine.
facts: Fact1: The studio releases the game product.
Fact2: The game passes quality testing.
Fact3: It is not the case that the game implements a cross-platform feature.
Fact4: It is not the case that the game achieves low sales.
Fact5: It is not the case that the project has adequate funding.
Fact6: It is not the case that the studio secures a major partnership.
